No matter where you stay, we hope you enjoy your visit to NYU and take advantage of the wonderful resources the City has to offer.   This list is provided for informational purposes only. While some of these hotels offer discounts for the NYU community, we neither endorse nor seek to promote any particular hotel. Name Distance to NYU, D.C. Amenities 2015 NYU Rates Near by   Club Quarters, Washington, D.C.   839 17th Street, NW   Washington, DC 2006   +1-202-974-4222  .7 Miles Complimentary Wi-Fi, Business Center, Gym For Club Room: $167-$207  For Standard Room:  $187-$227  For Superior Room:  $207-$247  For Suite: $237-$277 The White House, Washington Monument, The Capitol Building, The Mint, The National Archives, and The Smithsonian Museums         back to top ^           Chauffeur Service          Carey International, a global leader in ground transportation and chauffeur service, is now a preferred University vendor. Carey offers NYU two options of chauffeur service:     Carey International -- premier luxury sedans (Cadillac XTS and Lincoln Towncars)   Embarque -- economic option with environmentally-friendly vehicles (Toyota Prius+ and Toyota Camry)   University travelers will have access to both classes of service.                                                    Departmental Account Setup                               To set up a departmental account with Carey International, please send an e-mail to nyutraveler.info@nyu.edu requesting a departmental account set-up form.  Once you have a departmental account, you will have access to NYU-negotiated rates.  Payment options include:     Central billing   Corporate Travel Account   Purchase Order                                                                To Book Chauffeur Service                               You may use the following sites:     Carey - To book for one's own travel   Carey Connect - For departmental administrators responsible for booking travel for others   Embarque - To book one's own travel     To Call Carey     US Reservations: 1800-336-4646   International Desk: 1800-842-8420       To Call Embarque   General Reservations: 866-444-2144                                back to top ^               Car Rentals          For NYU Students, Faculty and Employees: Car rental reservations may be made via AMEX Travel or Egencia by clicking "BOOK" on the main page of NYU Traveler . By doing so your travel plans will be automatically transmitted to Worldcue, a traveler safety service NYU has enlisted to provide you with up-to-the-minute information of potential threats to your safety during your travels. If you wish to make a car rental reservation directly with the car rental provider, please see below.   NOTE: The insurance that is built into the NYU rental car rates is specific only to business travel. If you are utilizing the NYU rates for personal travel, you are encouraged to buy additional insurance at the front desk of the rental facility, as the insurance included in our rates will not cover incidents that occur while renting for personal use.                     AVIS          For NYU Students, Faculty and Employees ONLY                                                    Make an AVIS Reservation                               To make an Avis reservation, NYU staff, faculty, and students should return to the NYU Traveler Home Page and make their reservation using one of our preferred vendors: American Express Travel or Egencia.                                                                Enroll in AVIS Preferred Service                               For first time AVIS users, click here to enroll in AVIS PREFFERED SERVICE . Avis Preferred Service Membership is FREE and encouraged for NYU students, faculty and employees.Membership in Avis Preferred allows you to bypass the rental counter and go directly to your car, without waiting in line or for paperwork! Simply complete the online application and use your wizard number to make your reservation. Due to insurance requirements, only NYU Students, Faculty, and Employees may use this link.                       For NYU Friends and Family                                                      Make an AVIS Reservation                               Click here, to make a reservation using the NYU Friends and Family Discount .     In addition, the following coupons are available:     $25 Off Weekly Rental   Free Weekend Day   Free Upgrade   Two Free Days of GPS     Please note that the NYU Friends and Family Discount does not include insurance . You may purchase insurance through Avis at checkout, or opt to use your own if your credit card or automobile insurance policy includes insurance for rental cars.                            ENTERPRISE             For NYU Students, Faculty and Employees Only                                                    Make an ENTERPRISE Reservation                               To make an Enterprise reservation, NYU staff, faculty, and students should return to the NYU Traveler Home Page and make their reservation using one of our preferred vendors: American Express Travel or Egencia.                           back to top ^            Rail          AMTRAK          NYU has a contract with Amtrak which provides a 5% – 20% discount (determined by city pairs) on Acela Express Business Class service. The discount may ONLY be obtained by booking your Amtrak Acela Express reservation through AMEX Travel or Egencia. Please note, the discount will not be applied UNTIL clicking the final purchase button.             back to top ^                              On This Page     Hotels   Manhattan   Brooklyn   Washington, D.C. What's The Future of Alternative Fuel Vehicles in NYC and Beyond?                                                                                                               NYU.edu requires JavaScript be enabled in your browser in order to use important features of the site. JavaScript is either disabled or not supported by your browser. For instructions on how to enable JavaScript in your browser, click here . May 31, 2011                                          In a time of climate change and growing concerns about urban asthma rates, cutting one of the fast-growing sources of air pollutants and greenhouse gas emissions is increasingly viewed as paramount in the transportation sector.       On Tuesday, June 14, federal, state and city agency leaders, industry and labor officials, advocates and researchers will gather for a conference from 8:30 a.m. to 2:15 p.m. on what it takes to support alternative fuel vehicles broadly in the New York metro area and nationally.       The event – free and open to the public – will be held at NYU Kimmel Center (Eisner & Lubin Auditorium) 60 Washington Square South near the corner of LaGuardia Place, and is dubbed “ Alternative Fuel Vehicles and Infrastructure Requirements - Bringing Innovation To Our Streets .”       Craig Ivey, president of Con Edison of New York, will deliver the keynote address. He and many additional speakers will explore the market conditions as well as infrastructure investments, policies and strategies required to support green technologies.       The conference is sponsored by Rudin Center for Transportation Policy & Management at the Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service at New York University, along with NYS Energy Research & Development Authority, NYS Department of Transportation, and Con Edison.       RSVP is required: Visit http://wagner.nyu.edu/events/rudin-06-14-2011 or contact Robert Polner, NYU Office of Public Affairs, 212 998 2337, robert.polner@nyu.edu.                          This Press Release is in the following Topics:      Around the Square , Events and Traditions , Robert F. NYU Students Help City Crack Down on Hookah Bars   Capital New York reported that NYU students helped New York City crack down on hookah bars that illegally include tobacco in their hookahs:     Rudin Center Study Says Mass Transit Helps Economic Mobility   The Wall Street Journal wrote about a report by Wagner’s Rudin Center that showed that mass transit could be more important than education in determining economic mobility.     Brennan Center Report Says Campaign Spending Has Jumped   Frontline did a piece about a report by the Brennan Center for Justice that said that campaign spending by outside groups has more than doubled in the last five years.     NYU’s Dorms Ranked Among the Best in the Nation   Hometalk.com ranked NYU’s student residences third in the country in its list of best college dorms. What's The Future of Alternative Fuel Vehicles in NYC and Beyond? May 31, 2011                                          In a time of climate change and growing concerns about urban asthma rates, cutting one of the fast-growing sources of air pollutants and greenhouse gas emissions is increasingly viewed as paramount in the transportation sector.       On Tuesday, June 14, federal, state and city agency leaders, industry and labor officials, advocates and researchers will gather for a conference from 8:30 a.m. to 2:15 p.m. on what it takes to support alternative fuel vehicles broadly in the New York metro area and nationally.       The event – free and open to the public – will be held at NYU Kimmel Center (Eisner & Lubin Auditorium) 60 Washington Square South near the corner of LaGuardia Place, and is dubbed “ Alternative Fuel Vehicles and Infrastructure Requirements - Bringing Innovation To Our Streets .”       Craig Ivey, president of Con Edison of New York, will deliver the keynote address. He and many additional speakers will explore the market conditions as well as infrastructure investments, policies and strategies required to support green technologies.       The conference is sponsored by Rudin Center for Transportation Policy & Management at the Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service at New York University, along with NYS Energy Research & Development Authority, NYS Department of Transportation, and Con Edison.       RSVP is required: Visit http://wagner.nyu.edu/events/rudin-06-14-2011 or contact Robert Polner, NYU Office of Public Affairs, 212 998 2337, robert.polner@nyu.edu. Production Vehicles, Picture Cars, Subways: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Undergraduate Film & Television Admissions About the Program Course Offerings Summer Courses Showcase Internships Facilities Special Projects First Run & Festivals Calendar of Events News TSOA FTV Wiki Admin & Faculty Alumni Blog Facebook Twitter YouTube  home > Undergraduate Film & TV        Production Vehicles, Picture Cars, Subways  The following section outlines activities in film production that  require a thorough review by both the Department of Film & TV and the NYU Department of Insurance & Risk Management.  Students and instructors should  review  scripts and identify locations or set-ups that jeopardize or restrict  insurance coverage for the production. Also, coverage will not be  granted to locations where the general public is denied access due to  inherent risk (i.e. condemned property, airport runways, etc.). Here  are some common items/activities that must be cleared before approval can be granted: Aircraft Animals Bridges, Tunnels Cranes, Lifts, Jibs International Shoots Large Generators Simulated Firearms & Weapons Picture Cars Pyrotechnics Rooftops, Fire Escapes, Balconies Trains, Subways, Railroad Locations Water, Watercraft   Projects involving any of the items listed above must be discussed  in detail with the instructor. A full scene description and accompanying details  must also be filed via the 'Special Insurance Request' section of the  NYU Insurance web site: www.nyu.edu/insurance. Please note that this  process takes a minimum of two weeks to complete, so please plan  accordingly.     Policy On Insuring Production Vehicles, Picture Cars, Camera Cars, Process Trailers, and Moving Car Shots (Updated 7/21/2010) The University does not provide insurance for vehicles used on or in connection with student film productions, except when a vehicle is only being used as a stationary (non-moving) prop or background vehicles in the scene. Students who intend to use vehicles in film production that include but are not limited to personal cars, passenger vans, cargo vans, grip trucks, tracking vehicles, picture cars or moving car shots must satisfy the University's insurance and safety criteria, by adhering to the following: All vehicles used for the production (including personal cars and any vehicles carrying cast or crew) must carry a minimum of $1,000,000 in general liability insurance coverage. For rentals, a minimum of $1,000,000 in general liability insurance must be purchased from the rental company. The extra liability coverage is available from most rental companies and is called “additional or supplemental insurance.” Copies of rental reservation(s) will be required by the NYU Department of Insurance and Risk Management, with proof of the liability coverage attached. For personal cars, a copy of the owner's auto insurance policy must be provided, reflecting proof of the $1,000,000 coverage. If the existing coverage on the vehicle does not meet this requirement, then you will have to contact the auto insurance provider to purchase an additional 'umbrella' policy with a minimum of of $1,000,000 in order to meet the requirements. Such policies vary, so please contact the auto insurance provider for more information. In compliance with safety regulations, a passenger van may be used as long as its capacity does not exceed 12 persons. Insurance information for all vehicles must be submitted to the NYU Department of Insurance and Risk Management as soon as the vehicle(s) have been secured.      Policy on use of Pictures Cars & Moving Car Shots (Updated 7/21/2010)       This section refers to any vehicle, moving or non-moving, being depicted in the film frame or any vehicles associated with moving the camera, including but not limited to: Camera Cars, Shot Makers, lowboys, trailers, and flat beds. All students will be required to provide complete documentation and disclosure of any use of picture cars and any and all moving vehicles ($1,000,000 liability insurance requirements are compulsory).  Graduate students will be allowed to use picture cars with proper vetting by the Graduate faculty. Undergraduate Advanced-Level students will be allowed to use picture cars with proper vetting by the Instructor and the Production Supervision Committee. In order for the shot to be approved by the Supervision Committee, productions will be required in most cases to close off streets and secure permission/supervision from the local authorities where filming. Other rules may apply depending upon the circumstance. Students who have had their request approved will be required to have a final pre-production meeting with a faculty member from the Cinematography Area so that all production safety concerns can be addressed. Undergraduate Freshmen, Sophomore, Fundamentals, and Intermediate-level projects are not permitted to feature moving car shots. The following guidelines must be adhered to in order for a moving car shot to be approved for all student projects, Graduate and Undergraduate: There  are NO hood mounts, tray mounts or suction cup mounts allowed on any moving vehicle. Shooting From The Passenger Seat: Will be approved under limited circumstances, with proper vetting by the instructor, production supervisor(s), and Risk Management and the following must apply: a) Police supervision b) Street closing on either end c) Proof of $1,000,000 liability coverage on the vehicle. When actor does not need to be featured in the shot, a designated driver (licensed crew member) must drive the vehicle. Shooting From The Back Seat: Will be approved under limited circumstances, with proper vetting by the instructor, production supervisor(s), and Risk Management and the following must apply: a) Police supervision b) Street closing on either end c) Proof of $1,000,000 liability coverage on the vehicle. When the actor does not need to be featured in the shot, a designated driver (licensed crew member) must drive the vehicle. 'Poor Man's Process': Will be insured with proper approval by the instructor and production supervisor(s). This process allows for the simulation of a moving car shot with the use of lighting effects and minimal to no movement of the vehicle itself. Traveling Shots: Unless  the traveling shot is a tow with a properly equipped camera car, most  lights are not allowed for daytime shooting. Kinoflo’s are negotiable. For  night shooting, small plug-in (6 volt cigarette lighter) lights are  allowed For all circumstances: You  must supply a plan of how many people will be in the car in terms of cast  and crew. All vehicles must  have assigned drivers. Photocopies of their drivers’ licenses will be  required. All  picture car shots on New York City streets must be cleared with the  Mayor’s Office. Moving car  routes must be mapped out and approved by both the Mayor’s Office and the  NYPD Movie & TV Unit. Shoots  taking place on any public streets outside of NYC require local police  presence and the ability to close off streets. Film & TV and the Department of Insurance &  Risk Management will require copies of all permits and permissions which  must be granted by the local authorities. Filming on any roadway or street without these  requirements is strictly prohibited.  Please note that the Department of Film & TV reserves the right to change, alter, or modify these guidelines at any time, to comply with changes in the curriculum as well as changes to standard procedures set forth by the NYU Department of Insurance & Risk Management                          Subway Scenes There is NO insurance coverage for shoots within 50 feet of subway platforms, tracks, or moving trains. No exceptions! If you would like to shoot  near the entrance of or by the turnstile of a subway station you must  contact the MTA Office of Film & Special Events (646) 252-5853, or  visit them online: www.mta.info/nyct/sub_filming/filming.htm . Keep  in mind that the MTA charges a substantial fee for subway shoots and  does not offer any student discounts or waivers. You must contact  them at the number given above for further details. An  alternative to shooting on or in the subway is the New York Transit  Museum. However, they al so charge a fee of approximately $1000.00 for  every 6 hours of shooting (subject to change). You must contact them  Transit Museum for further details, (718) 243-3060 Other Subway & Railroad Locations Other railroad locations may be available, but you must do a thorough scout and make contact with the office in charge of granting permission for you to film at that location. If permission can be granted, you must submit the proper insured's information on an insurance request form, along with details about the location and the scene you plan to shoot. Please note that the maximum two-week turnaround is needed to process your request, and additional fees for special railroad coverage may be required.
